Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Acquisition of an Integrated System of Instruments for Multichannel Biopotential Recording of In-vitro and In-vivo Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the Norfolk State University (NSU) to build an integrative research platform for neural recording and analysis and provide the resources for students, faculty and associated collaborators for their research activities from electronic and optical engineering, biology, computer science, nanotechnology, immunology, and neuroscience fields. The addition of this system to the existing research infrastructures will directly benefit and upgrade investigator?s research programs at NSU, Eastern Virginia Medical School and Old Dominion University, as well as the collaborative network capabilities in the Hampton Roads area. Applying the multichannel biopotential recording system, neural and cardiac potentials, and neurochemicals such as neurotransmitters can be measured in-vivo and in-vitro, and analyzed by embedded software. The instrument will be applied for the study of neural mechanisms underlying the interactions under various behavioral, stimuli, and disease conditions. In addition to the biopotential recording, the instrumentation will allow in-vivo assessment of neural sensing devices to be developed by engineering research. Furthermore, in-vivo and in-vitro real-time measurement and monitoring of sensing signal can be applied for the development of novel therapeutic treatment strategies of neurological disorders and degeneration.

The outcomes of this synergetic research will be positively transferred to achieve their STEM educational and outreach goals, especially focused for under-represented minority (URM) students in the project?s leading institution, NSU, one of the largest Historically Black Colleges and Universities in the U.S. This project will specifically place a high priority on training of URM students in Hampton Roads region and extend their efforts to URM students nationwide through an aggressive set of research, training and outreach activities utilizing current outreach programs on each campus. The outcomes of this project will be incorporated in their Bioengineering Minor program curriculum. Furthermore, they will also integrate this infrastructure with activity of the newly created Hampton Roads Neuroscience Network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is to acquire an integrated system of instruments which can measure neural signals in-vivo and in-vitro and provide easy access to investigators in universities and institutions in Hampton Roads area. The acquired instrumentation are an 128-Channel Neural Recording and Stimulation System (April 21, 2014) and a Functional Near Infrared Neuro-Imaging System. For easy access and use at collaborative and interdisciplinary research programs. these systems were easily transported and quickly set up for various experimental paradigms. Norfolk State University as the leading institute served as a hub and provided easy and on-time access and maintenance to the shared instrument.  

Through this two year project period, there were significant outcomes in research activities and infrastructure. First, the new infrastructure strongly supported existing research projects and collaborations by allowing the measurement of neural signals (unit action potentials and local field potentials) and animal behaviors, in-vivo and in-vitro in real time, and the analysis of measured signals using the on-line and off-line software. Multiple research projected were highly benefited by the instrumentation including 1) Multichannel Neural Recording for Hybrid Neural Sensing and Stimulation System Development, 2) Optogenetic Stimulation and Neural Recording at Mesopontine Region and its Modulation by the Amygdala and Stress, and 3) Functional Near Infrared Neural Recording for Detection of Distracted Driving by Cell Phone Texting

Second, due to the nature of neuroscience and engineering research and development, adding this new instrumentation initiated new opportunities for interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary research collaboration in this region in a variety of areas including electronic and optical engineering, material science, mathematics, biology, chemistry, computer science, nanotechnology, and neuroscience. Many of the research of the investigators in this project are closely related each other and leaded research collaboration and projects. Developed research collaboration and instrumentation significantly upgraded the scope of research and provided new research opportunities and additional funding from other agencies for further collaboration.

Third, the new instrumentation also provided a fundamental training resource not previously available in the Hampton Roads area. We especially focused on training of under-represented minority (URM) students in the project’s leading institution, NSU, and URM students in Hampton Roads region. NSU is one of the largest HBCUs in the nation with approximately 81% of the total student population and about 65% of the female student population being African Americans. This infrastructure significantly increased the participation of minority groups on all degree levels by providing students with cutting-edge neural engineering research opportunities. Through these collaborating research activities using the acquired systems, students accentuated their interest and knowledge in STEM-H fields and learned workmanship roles in the interdisciplinary research environments for their future careers.
